DOCNAME: CASE OF MARKOVIC AND OTHERS v. ITALY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court)
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Egbert Myjer;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Ján Šikuta;Jean-Paul Costa;John Hedigan;Karel Jungwiert;Lucius Caflisch;Luzius Wildhaber;Margarita Tsatsa-Nikolovska;Mindia Ugrekhelidze;Nicolas Bratza;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The CARDINAL applicants are all citizens of GPE and GPE , which was known at the time of the events in question as GPE ( “ the FRY ” ) .
The first CARDINAL applicants , PERSON and PERSON , were born in DATE respectively , and applied to the ORG on behalf of PERSON , deceased son of PERSON and brother of PERSON .
The third and fourth applicants , PERSON and PERSON , were born in DATE and DATE respectively , and applied to the ORG on behalf of PERSON , deceased husband of PERSON and father of PERSON .
The fifth applicant , PERSON , was born in DATE and applied to the ORG on behalf of her deceased husband , PERSON .
The sixth and seventh applicants , PERSON and PERSON , were born in DATE and DATE respectively , and applied to the ORG on behalf of PERSON , deceased son of PERSON and brother of PERSON .
The DATE and tenth applicants , PERSON , GPE and PERSON , were born in DATE respectively , and applied to the ORG on behalf of PERSON , deceased son of PERSON and PERSON and brother of PERSON .
CARDINAL . The applicants lodged the present application to complain of the outcome of an action in damages which they had brought in the NORP courts in respect of an air strike against the FRY .

CARDINAL . The facts of the case relate to the same events as those considered by ORG in its decision in the case of PERSON and Others v. GPE and Others ( ( dec . ) [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-XII ) . The facts in that case were summarised as follows :

“ CARDINAL . The conflict in GPE between NORP and NORP forces during DATE and DATE is well documented . Against the background of the escalating conflict , together with the growing concerns and unsuccessful diplomatic initiatives of the international community , the CARDINAL - nation ORG ( established in DATE by ORG ) met and agreed to convene negotiations between the parties to the conflict .

CARDINAL . On DATE , and following a decision of its ORG ( NAC ) , ORG ( ORG ) announced air strikes on the territory of the ORG in the case of non - compliance with the demands of the international community . Negotiations consequently took place between the parties to the conflict from CARDINAL to DATE in ORG and from DATE in GPE . The resulting proposed peace agreement was signed by the NORP delegation but not by the NORP delegation .

CARDINAL . Considering that all efforts to achieve a negotiated political solution to the GPE crisis had failed , the ORG decided on , and on DATE the Secretary General of ORG announced , the beginning of air strikes ( ORG ) against the ORG . The air strikes lasted from DATE to CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . CARDINAL television channels and CARDINAL radio stations operated from the ORG facilities in GPE . The main production facilities were housed in CARDINAL buildings at FAC . The master control room was housed on the first floor of CARDINAL of the buildings and was staffed mainly by technical staff .

CARDINAL . On DATE , just after TIME approximately , CARDINAL of the ORG buildings at FAC was hit by a missile launched from a FAC aircraft . CARDINAL of the CARDINAL floors of the building collapsed and the master control room was destroyed .
CARDINAL . ... CARDINAL targets were hit in the FRY that night , including CARDINAL in GPE . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The partial collapse of the ORG building caused the deaths of CARDINAL people , including the CARDINAL relatives of the applicants .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first CARDINAL applicants brought an action in damages in the GPE ORG under Article CARDINAL of the NORP Civil Code . The other CARDINAL applicants applied to be joined to the proceedings on DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicants believed that civil liability for the deaths of their relatives lay with the NORP Prime Minister ’s ORG and with ORG in LOC ( ORG ) .

They argued that the NORP courts had jurisdiction to hear the case . In particular , on the basis of the wording of LAW , they submitted that the unlawful act that had caused the alleged damage should be regarded as having been committed in GPE inasmuch as the military action had been organised on NORP territory and part of it had taken place there . They based this argument on the extent of GPE ’s commitment – involving substantial political and logistical support DATE to the military mission in question . Specifically , GPE , unlike other ORG members , had provided the air bases from which the aircraft that had bombed GPE and the ORG had taken off . They also relied in support of their claim on LAW and on LAW of DATE and LAW to LAW .
CARDINAL . The defendants argued that the NORP courts had no jurisdiction to hear the case . The proceedings against ORG were discontinued by the applicants .
CARDINAL . The Prime Minister ’s Office and ORG subsequently sought a preliminary ruling from ORG on the question of jurisdiction ( regolamento preventivo di giurisdizione ) under LAW .

CARDINAL . In written submissions dated DATE , ORG at ORG argued that the application for a preliminary ruling should be declared inadmissible as it concerned the merits of the claim , not the issue of jurisdiction . He stated as follows :
“ The governmental bodies defending this claim have requested a preliminary ruling on the issue of jurisdiction , arguing that :

( a ) since the action is brought against the NORP ORG as a specific ( unitary ) subject of international law for acts performed in the exercise of its imperium ( iure imperii ) , it can not be brought in the NORP courts ;

( b ) paragraph CARDINAL of Article VIII of LAW of DATE , which GPE ratified by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE , does not provide any basis for the action either , as it applies to damage caused in the receiving ORG .

The government seek to show through this jurisdictional issue that the NORP legal system does not contain any provision or principle capable of providing a basis for the alleged personal right [ diritto soggettivo perfetto ] or of guaranteeing it in the abstract .
Accordingly , the position is that :
( a ) NORP the government argue that the NORP ORG can not be held liable for acts carried out in the exercise of its imperium ;

( b ) in addition , they deny that the said ORG can be used to determine the place where the acts which caused the alleged damage took place ( it is not by accident that the applicant has cited the provisions of LAW referring to the place where the offence was committed ) .
It follows that the questions thus raised go to the merits , not to the issue of jurisdiction ( see judgment no . CARDINAL of DATE of ORG , sitting as a full court ) .
For these reasons , ORG , sitting as a full court , is asked to declare the application inadmissible , with all the consequences which that entails in law . ”

CARDINAL . In a ruling ( no . DATE ) of DATE , which was deposited with the registry on DATE and conveyed to the applicants on DATE , ORG , sitting as a full court ( ORG ) , found that the NORP courts had no jurisdiction . It reasoned as follows :

CARDINAL . NORP The claim seeks to impute liability to the NORP ORG on the basis of an act of war , in particular the conduct of hostilities through aerial warfare . The choice of the means that will be used to conduct hostilities is an act of government . These are acts through which political functions are performed and the LAW provides for them to be assigned to a constitutional body . The nature of such functions precludes any claim to a protected interest in relation thereto , so that the acts by which they are carried out may or may not have a specific content – see the judgments of the full court of CARDINAL DATE ( no . CARDINAL ) , CARDINAL DATE ( no . DATE ) and DATE ( no . CARDINAL ) . With respect to acts of this type , no court has the power to review the manner in which the function was performed .

CARDINAL . While the purpose of the provisions of international agreements governing the conduct of hostilities – LAW to LAW ( Articles CARDINAL , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE ) and LAW ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL § DATE is to protect civilians in the event of attack , they are rules of international law , and so also regulate relations between GPE .

These same treaties lay down the procedure for finding a violation and the sanctions in the event of liability ( LAW and LAW ) ; they also designate the international courts and tribunals with jurisdiction to make such a finding .

However , the legislation implementing these rules in the NORP ORG does not contain any express provision enabling injured parties to seek reparation from the ORG for damage sustained as a result of a violation of the rules of international law .

The notion that provisions to that effect may implicitly have been introduced into the system through the implementation of rules of international law is at odds with the converse principle that has been mentioned which holds that protected individual interests are no bar to carrying out functions of a political nature .

Indeed , in order to enable reparation to be provided in the domestic system for loss sustained as a result of a violation of the ‘ reasonable time’ requirement under LAW , [ the ORG ] introduced appropriate legislation ( PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE ) .
CARDINAL . No entitlement to a review of the government ’s decision concerning the conduct of hostilities with respect to the ORG aerial operations against ORG can be found in LAW of DATE .

The fact that the aircraft used to bomb the GPE radio and television station were able to use bases situated on NORP territory constitutes but CARDINAL element of the highly complex operation whose lawfulness it is sought to review and is not therefore relevant to the application of the rule laid down in paragraph CARDINAL of Article VIII of the Convention , which on the contrary presupposes the commission of an act that is amenable to review . ”
CARDINAL . ORG ruling brought to an end , ipso jure , the proceedings in ORG .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW are as follows :
“ The NORP legal system shall comply with the generally recognised rules of international law .
“ Everyone may bring legal proceedings to protect his or her rights and legitimate interests .

“ Civil servants , other agents of the ORG and public entities shall be directly responsible , in accordance with the criminal , civil and administrative law , for acts committed in breach of rights . In connection with such acts , civil liability shall extend to the ORG and public entities .
“ Judicial protection of rights and legitimate interests in the ordinary and administrative courts shall always lie against acts of the public administrative authorities .
It may not be excluded or limited to extraordinary remedies or specific categories of act .
The law shall specify which judicial bodies are empowered to set aside acts of the public authorities , in what cases and with what effects . ”
CARDINAL . DATE of LAW no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE provides :
“ No appeal to the Consiglio di Stato , sitting in its judicial capacity , shall lie against acts or decisions of the government which involve the exercise of political power . ”
CARDINAL . DATE of the Civil Code provides :
“ Any unlawful act which causes damage to another will render the perpetrator liable in damages under the civil law . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure , which deals with the issue of jurisdiction , provides :

“ For so long as there has been no determination of the merits of the proceedings at first instance , any party may seek a ruling on a question of jurisdiction under LAW from ORG , sitting as a full court . ... ”
LAW provides :

“ A ruling that an ordinary court has no jurisdiction because the case concerns a public authority or is within the province of a special court may be made at any time and at any level of jurisdiction , including by the court of its own motion . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The relevant provisions of LAW provide :
“ Anyone who commits an offence on the territory of the ORG shall be punished in accordance with NORP law .

The offence will be regarded as having been committed on the territory of the ORG if all or part of the act or omission at the origin of the offence or all or some of the consequences of such act or omission occurred there . ”
“ ORG and compensation for damage .
The commission of an offence shall give rise to an obligation of restitution under the civil law [ Articles DATE et seq . of LAW ] .

Any offence that causes pecuniary damage [ Article CARDINAL of LAW ] or non - pecuniary damage [ Article CARDINAL of LAW ] shall impose an obligation on the perpetrator and those accountable for his or her actions under the civil law [ Article CARDINAL of LAW ] to make reparation . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of ORG reads as follows :

“ A commanding officer of a military force who , in order to inflict damage on the enemy , orders or authorises the use of a means or method of warfare that is prohibited by law or by international treaty or which is in any event contrary to the military code of honour shall be liable on conviction to a minimum of DATE imprisonment unless the act concerned is a criminal offence under a specific statutory provision .
If the act results in a massacre , the minimum term of imprisonment shall be DATE . ”

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE ( no . PERSON ) , ORG , sitting as a full court , established the rule that the courts had no jurisdiction to hear cases against the authorities relating to political acts .

A trade union had brought an action against the Prime Minister , ORG and ORG on the ground that the government had failed to comply with their undertakings . ORG noted , inter alia , that such a failure could only engage the government ’s political responsibility , but could not create a right . It ruled that the courts had no jurisdiction to hear the case after formulating the following principle :

“ Legislative action is a political act since it is the standard means of performing political and governmental functions . The governmental authority ’s conduct in the present case was not , therefore , capable in law of causing individuals damage ( whether to their personal rights or to their legitimate interests ) ; it consequently escapes all judicial scrutiny . ”

CARDINAL . The NORP courts had in fact already examined this question in a number of earlier cases and had ruled that , as they were political in nature , the following acts escaped the scrutiny of the domestic courts :

( i ) a waiver of the right to exercise jurisdiction LAW between the Parties to LOC the Status of their ORG , DATE , no . CARDINAL , GPE and Others , ORG . Pen . [ Criminal Justice ] , DATE , III , p. CARDINAL ) ;

( ii ) NORP the assignment of property belonging to NORP nationals under LAW of DATE ( Court of Cassation , sitting as a full court , CARDINAL DATE , no . CARDINAL , ORG v. the ORG , PERSON diritto internazionale [ ORG ] , DATE , p. CARDINAL ) ;
( iii ) a Transport Ministry decree suspending permission to transport goods to GPE ( ORG , CARDINAL DATE , LOC . S. and PERSON . ORG v. ORG , PERSON [ ORG Procedure ] , DATE , p. CARDINAL ) ;
( iv ) a decision by ORG appointing employees’ representatives as delegates to ORG ( ORG , DATE , no . CARDINAL , ORG , ORG , DATE , p. CARDINAL ) ;
( v ) a declaration of war and treaty provisions relating to compensation for war damage ( ORG ( I ) , DATE , no . CARDINAL , PERSON the ORG , ORG . PERSON . Reg . [ ORG ] , DATE , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The full court of ORG delivered a further judgment ( no . DATE ) on DATE . It concerned the jurisdiction of the NORP civil courts to hear claims for compensation for damage sustained by a person who had been captured by the NORP military in DATE and deported to work for NORP industry . GPE had pleaded State immunity and the courts of first instance and appeal had held that they had no jurisdiction to make an order against it . ORG carried out a very extensive examination of the international treaties on international crime , imprescriptibility , the international responsibility of GPE , immunity from jurisdiction and of the case - law of various international tribunals . In holding that the immunity plea failed and the NORP courts had to decide the claim , it stated inter alia :

“ ... In a decision no . CARDINAL of DATE , this full court did indeed rule that acts performed by the ORG in the conduct of hostilities escape all scrutiny by the courts , as they are acts through which ‘ political’ functions are carried out . The nature of these functions ‘ precludes any claim to a protected interest in respect thereto , so that there may or may not be a specific content to the acts through which they are performed’ . Pursuant to this principle , the NORP courts were held to have no jurisdiction to hear a claim against the NORP Prime Minister ’s Office and ORG for compensation for the destruction of a non - military objective during ORG air strikes against ORG or for the resultant civilian deaths . It is readily apparent , however , firstly , that the fact that the court can not contest the manner in which the actions of the supreme head of the res publica are conducted does not prevent it from finding that a criminal offence has been committed or that there is related liability under the criminal or civil law ( Articles CARDINAL of the LAW ; section LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE ; and LAW no . DATE ) ; secondly , by virtue of the principle of adaptation established by LAW , the ‘ generally recognised’ principles of international law which govern the fundamental values constituted by the freedom and dignity of the human being and characterise the most serious assaults upon the integrity of those values as ‘ international crimes’ have ‘ ORG been integrated into our system and are entirely apt for use as a standard whereby the injustice of damage caused to others by intentional or negligent ‘ acts’ may be gauged . It is evident , therefore , that the principles referred to in this decision can not be taken into consideration in the instant case . ...

CARDINAL Granting immunity from jurisdiction to GPE who have been guilty of such wrongdoing is in manifest contradiction with the aforementioned normative rules because it constitutes an obstacle to the defence of values whose protection , like these norms and principles , must on the contrary be considered essential for the entire international community , even to the point of justifying forms of mandatory response in the most serious cases . Nor is there any doubt that the antinomy must be resolved by giving priority to the highest ranking norms , as the judges in the minority ( CARDINAL to CARDINAL ) stated in their dissenting opinion appended to the judgment in PERSON [ v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . ORG , ORG CARDINAL-XI ] , by precluding in such cases any claim by the ORG to immunity from suit in the foreign courts . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE the NORP government decided to send a military expeditionary force to GPE to perform peacekeeping operations . After the expeditionary force had returned to GPE , it was discovered that some of its members had engaged in the torture of NORP prisoners . CARDINAL members of the expedition were charged and given prison sentences . They were also ordered to pay compensation to the civil party . In judgment no . CARDINAL of DATE , the text of which was deposited with the registry on DATE , ORG ordered another NORP serviceman and ORG to make reparation for the damage sustained by the relatives of a civilian whom the serviceman had killed unlawfully .

CARDINAL . The applicants relied in the domestic courts on LAW DATE to LAW of CARDINAL DATE , relating to ORG . The LAW , which GPE ratified through Law no . CARDINAL of DATE , contains , inter alia , the following provisions :
“ CARDINAL . In any armed conflict , the right of the Parties to the conflict to choose methods or means of warfare is not unlimited .
CARDINAL . It is prohibited to employ weapons , projectiles and material and methods of warfare of a nature to cause superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering .
CARDINAL . It is prohibited to employ methods or means of warfare which are intended , or may be expected , to cause widespread , long - term and severe damage to the natural environment .

“ In order to ensure respect for and protection of the civilian population and civilian objects , the Parties to the conflict shall at all times distinguish between the civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objectives and accordingly shall direct their operations only against military objectives . ”
“ CARDINAL . CARDINAL ’Attacks’ means acts of violence against the adversary , whether in offence or in defence .

CARDINAL . NORP The provisions of this LAW with respect to attacks apply to all attacks in whatever territory conducted , including the national territory belonging to a ORG to the conflict but under the control of an adverse ORG .

CARDINAL . The provisions of this section apply to any land , air or sea warfare which may affect the civilian population , individual civilians or civilian objects on land . They further apply to all attacks from the sea or from the air against objectives on land but do not otherwise affect the rules of international law applicable in armed conflict at sea or in the air .

CARDINAL . The provisions of this section are additional to the rules concerning humanitarian protection contained in LAW , particularly in Part II thereof , and in other international agreements binding upon LAW , as well as to other rules of international law relating to the protection of civilians and civilian objects on land , at sea or in the air against the effects of hostilities . ”

“ CARDINAL . The civilian population and individual civilians shall enjoy general protection against dangers arising from military operations . To give effect to this protection , the following rules , which are additional to other applicable rules of international law , shall be observed in all circumstances .

CARDINAL . NORP The civilian population as such , as well as individual civilians , shall not be the object of attack . Acts or threats of violence the primary purpose of which is to spread terror among the civilian population are prohibited .
CARDINAL . Civilians shall enjoy the protection afforded by this section , unless and for such time as they take a direct part in hostilities .
CARDINAL . Indiscriminate attacks are prohibited . Indiscriminate attacks are :
( a ) those which are not directed at a specific military objective ;
( b ) those which employ a method or means of combat which can not be directed at a specific military objective ; or
( c ) those which employ a method or means of combat the effects of which can not be limited as required by this LAW ;
and consequently , in each such case , are of a nature to strike military objectives and civilians or civilian objects without distinction .
CARDINAL . Among others , the following types of attacks are to be considered as indiscriminate :

( a ) an attack by bombardment by any methods or means which treats as a single military objective a number of clearly separated and distinct military objectives located in a city , town , village or other area containing a similar concentration of civilians or civilian objects ;
and

( b ) an attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life , injury to civilians , damage to civilian objects , or a combination thereof , which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated .
CARDINAL . Attacks against the civilian population or civilians by way of reprisals are prohibited .

CARDINAL . The presence or movements of the civilian population or individual civilians shall not be used to render certain points or areas immune from military operations , in particular in attempts to shield military objectives from attacks or to shield , favour or impede military operations . The Parties to the conflict shall not direct the movement of the civilian population or individual civilians in order to attempt to shield military objectives from attacks or to shield military operations .

CARDINAL . Any violation of these prohibitions shall not release the Parties to the conflict from their legal obligations with respect to the civilian population and civilians , including the obligation to take the precautionary measures provided for in LAW .
“ CARDINAL . Civilian objects shall not be the object of attack or of reprisals . Civilian objects are all objects which are not military objectives as defined in paragraph CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . Attacks shall be limited strictly to military objectives . In so far as objects are concerned , military objectives are limited to those objects which by their nature , location , purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction , capture or neutralization , in the circumstances ruling at the time , offers a definite military advantage .

CARDINAL . NORP In case of doubt whether an object which is normally dedicated to civilian purposes , such as a place of worship , a house or other dwelling or a school , is being used to make an effective contribution to military action , it shall be presumed not to be so used .
“ CARDINAL . In the conduct of military operations , constant care shall be taken to spare the civilian population , civilians and civilian objects .
CARDINAL . With respect to attacks , the following precautions shall be taken :
( a ) those who plan or decide upon an attack shall :

( i ) do everything feasible to verify that the objectives to be attacked are neither civilians nor civilian objects and are not subject to special protection but are military objectives within the meaning of paragraph CARDINAL of LAW and that it is not prohibited by the provisions of this LAW to attack them ;

( ii ) take all feasible precautions in the choice of means and methods of attack with a view to avoiding , and in any event to minimizing , incidental loss or civilian life , injury to civilians and damage to civilian objects ;

( iii ) refrain from deciding to launch any attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life , injury to civilians , damage to civilian objects , or a combination thereof , which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated ;

( b ) an attack shall be cancelled or suspended if it becomes apparent that the objective is not a military one or is subject to special protection or that the attack may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life , injury to civilians , damage to civilian objects , or a combination thereof , which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated ;
( c ) NORP effective advance warning shall be given of attacks which may affect the civilian population , unless circumstances do not permit .

CARDINAL . When a choice is possible between several military objectives for obtaining a similar military advantage , the objective to be selected shall be that the attack on which may be expected to cause the least danger to civilian lives and to civilian objects .

CARDINAL . In the conduct of military operations at sea or in the air , each ORG to the conflict shall , in conformity with its rights and duties under the rules of international law applicable in armed conflict , take all reasonable precautions to avoid losses of civilian lives and damage to civilian objects .
CARDINAL . No provision of this Article may be construed as authorizing any attacks against the civilian population , civilians or civilian objects .

“ A ORG to the conflict which violates the provisions of the ORG or of this LAW shall , if the case demands , be liable to pay compensation . It shall be responsible for all acts committed by persons forming part of its armed forces . ”

CARDINAL . The applicants also relied in the domestic courts on paragraph CARDINAL of Article VIII of LAW of DATE between the Parties to the North Atlantic Treaty regarding the Status of their ORG , which GPE ratified through Law no . CARDINAL of DATE .
Article I defines certain terms as follows :
( d ) ’sending State’ means ORG to which the force belongs ;
( e ) ’receiving PERSON means ORG in the territory of which the force or civilian component is located , whether it be stationed there or passing in transit ;
Article PERSON provides , inter alia :

CARDINAL . Claims ( other than contractual claims and those to which paragraphs CARDINAL or CARDINAL of this Article apply ) arising out of acts or omissions of members of a force or civilian component done in the performance of official duty , or out of any other act , omission or occurrence for which a force or civilian component is legally responsible , and causing damage in the territory of the receiving ORG to third parties , other than any of the Contracting Parties , shall be dealt with by the receiving ORG in accordance with the following provisions :

( a ) Claims shall be filed , considered and settled or adjudicated in accordance with the laws and regulations of the receiving ORG with respect to claims arising from the activities of its own armed forces .
( b ) The receiving ORG may settle any such claims , and payment of the amount agreed upon or determinated by adjudication shall be made by the receiving ORG in its currency .

( c ) Such payment , whether made pursuant to a settlement or to adjudication of the case by a competent tribunal of the receiving ORG , or the final adjudication by such a tribunal denying payment , shall be binding and conclusive upon the Contracting Parties .

( d ) Every claim paid by the receiving ORG shall be communicated to the sending States concerned together with full particulars and a proposed distribution in conformity with sub - paragraphs ( e ) ( i ) , ( ii ) and ( iii ) below . In default of a reply within DATE , the proposed distribution shall be regarded as accepted .
( e ) The cost incurred in satisfying claims pursuant to the preceding sub - paragraphs and paragraph CARDINAL of this Article shall be distributed between the Contracting Parties , as follows :

( i ) Where CARDINAL sending ORG alone is responsible , the amount awarded or adjudged shall be distributed in the proportion of MONEY chargeable to the receiving ORG and MONEY chargeable to the sending ORG .

( ii ) Where CARDINAL ORG is responsible for the damage , the amount awarded or adjudged shall be distributed equally among them : however , if the receiving ORG is not CARDINAL of the GPE responsible , its contribution shall be CARDINAL that of each of the sending States .

( iii ) Where the damage was caused by the armed services of the Contracting Parties and it is not possible to attribute it specifically to one or more of those armed services , the amount awarded or adjudged shall be distributed equally among the Contracting Parties concerned : however , if the receiving ORG is not CARDINAL of the GPE by whose armed services the damage was caused , its contribution shall be CARDINAL that of each of the sending States concerned .

( iv ) Every DATE , a statement of the sums paid by the receiving ORG in the course of DATE in respect of every case regarding which the proposed distribution on a percentage basis has been accepted , shall be sent to the sending States concerned , together with a request for reimbursement . Such reimbursement shall be made within the shortest possible time , in the currency of the receiving ORG .

( f ) In cases where the application of the provisions of sub - paragraphs ( b ) and ( e ) of this paragraph would cause a ORG serious hardship , it may request ORG to arrange a settlement of a different nature .

( g ) A member of a force or civilian component shall not be subject to any proceedings for the enforcement of any judgment given against him in the receiving ORG in a matter arising from the performance of his official duties .

( h ) Except in so far as sub - paragraph ( e ) of this paragraph applies to claims covered by paragraph CARDINAL of this LAW , the provisions of this paragraph shall not apply to any claim arising out of or in connexion with the navigation or operation of a ship or the loading , carriage , or discharge of a cargo , other than claims for death or personal injury to which paragraph CARDINAL of this Article does not apply .

CARDINAL . Claims against members of a force or civilian component arising out of tortious acts or omissions in the receiving ORG not done in the performance of official duty shall be dealt with in the following manner :
( b ) The report shall be delivered to the authorities of the sending ORG , who shall then decide without delay whether they will offer an ex gratia payment , and if so , of what amount .

( c ) If an offer of ex gratia payment is made , and accepted by the claimant in full satisfaction of his claim , the authorities of the sending State shall make the payment themselves and inform the authorities of the receiving ORG of their decision and of the sum paid .

( d ) Nothing in this paragraph shall affect the jurisdiction of the courts of the receiving ORG to entertain an action against a member of a force or of a civilian component unless and until there has been payment in full satisfaction of the claim .

CARDINAL . Claims arising out of the unauthorized use of any vehicle of the armed services of a sending ORG shall be dealt with in accordance with paragraph CARDINAL of this LAW , except in so far as the force or civilian component is legally responsible .

CARDINAL . If a dispute arises as to whether a tortious act or omission of a member of a force or civilian component was done in the performance of official duty or as to whether the use of any vehicle of the armed services of a sending ORG was unauthorized , the question shall be submitted to an arbitrator appointed in accordance with paragraph CARDINAL ( b ) of this Article , whose decision on this point shall be final and conclusive .

CARDINAL . The sending ORG shall not claim immunity from the jurisdiction of the courts of the receiving ORG for members of a force or civilian component in respect of the civil jurisdiction of the courts of the receiving ORG except to the extent provided in paragraph CARDINAL ( g ) of this Article .

CARDINAL . The authorities of the sending ORG and of the receiving ORG shall co - operate in the procurement of evidence for a fair hearing and disposal of claims in regard to which the Contracting Parties are concerned .
